author: Chris Oberholtz, Multimedia Producer
title: Fans hold church service at Arrowhead before Chiefs game
text:
KANSAS CITY, MO (KCTV) - For those who always wanted to go to a Chiefs home game but didn’t want to skip out on Sunday church services, fan are in luck.
Now, they can sing hymns while wearing Chiefs’ gear.
They say people can’t be in two places at once, but at Arrowhead Stadium, that’s not necessarily the case.
The tailgating scene outside Arrowhead Stadium during a Chiefs home game is something anyone can expect. But inside the Chiefs Chapel tent, it is a much different scene. It is a place where fans can come and worship before every noon home game.
"We're just trying to match the enthusiasm by having a church service here at Arrowhead," said Marcellus Casey, director of Kansas City’s Fellowship of Christian Athletes.
Two years ago, Kansas City’s FCA partnered with the Chiefs to offer the non-denominational service. It gives die-hard fans the chance to attend the game, without having to missing their Sunday devotional.
"A lot of times, you'll see or someone will say, 'Hey I was here last year for one or two,' and thanks for putting these on," chapel volunteer Jeremy McTaggert said.
Chiefs chaplain Phillip Kelley leads the services which include plenty of music and a guest speaker. Inside the chapel, the rivalries are put aside, even if it’s just for 45 minutes.
"Everybody’s welcome," McTaggert said.
And Sunday, Steelers fans are invited too. All services begin at 9:30 a.m. and last until about 10:15 a.m. - just enough time to grill some burgers and brats before kickoff.
